titleStmt.title: J.J. Johnson v. William Billings. Writ

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.title: J.J. Johnson v. William Billings. Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In the matter of the application of J.J. Johnson for a writ of Habeas corpus
To the Hon. Roger S. Greene Judge of the District Court of the 2nd Judicial District of Washington Territory holding terms at Olympia.

The petition of respectfully shows; That one J.J. Johnson is unlawfully imprisoned, detained and confined and restrained of his liberty by William Billings, Sheriff and Keeper of the County Jail of Thurston County at the jail of said County in said Territory.
That the said imprisonment, detention, confinement and restraint are illegal and that the illegality thereof consists in this to wit:

The said William Billings as keeper of said jail claims the right to imprison, detain, confine and restrain said J.J. Johnson of his liberty under and by virtue of a commitment issued by the Clerk of said Court under the seal thereof bearing date the 14th day of December 1874 commanding him to imprison the said J.J. Johnson in said jail for the period of 3 months therein next serving and in default of the payment of the sum of three hundred dollars and unto of writ to still further imprison the said J.J. Johnson until the payment of said amount not to exceed 3 months in addition thereto.

That the said J.J. Johnson was on the 25th day of November 1874 indicted by the Grand Jury of the United States at said term of court, to inquire of offenses com- mitted against the law of the United States and that he was charged in said indictment with having sold and given spirituous liquors in said District to certain Indians therein named, subsequent to the 22nd day of June 1874 said Indians being then and there under this charge of now Indian Superintendent. That upon being arraigned in said Court on the 27th day of November 1874 he plead guilty of said indictment and that on the 14th day of December 1874 the said Court reduced judgment therein against said J.J. Johnson and by of this premises then and there considered that said J.J. Johnson be imprisoned in said County jail for the period of 3 months and that he pays a fine of three hundred dollars and the costs of said action and that he be further imprisoned until said costs and time are paid not to exceed three months additional. That said J.J. Johnson has been con- tinually imprisoned and restrained of his liberty by said William Billings at said County jail since said 14th day of November 1874; That said indict- ment does not charge said J.J. Johnson with any offense against the law of the United States or other crime; that he was not duly and legally convicted of any offense whatever; that said indictment does not show that the sale and giving said spirituous liquors to said Indians by said J.J. Johnson was done by him in an Indian Country; that said judgment of said court at the time of the thereof was and now is illegal and void

Wherefore your petitioner prays that a writ of habeas corpus may be granted, directed to the said William Billings, com- manding him to have the body of the said J.J. Johnson before your Honor at a time and place theretin to be specified, to do and receive, what shall then and there be considered by your Honor concerning him together with the time and cause of his detention and said writ and that he may be restored to his liberty.
Sworn to and subscribed before me this 27th day of March 1875 J.H. Houghton Clerk
